p: A growing number of pre-clinical studies and clinical trials have advanced our understanding of how live attenuated influenza vaccines (LAIVs) elicit mucosal antibodies via intranasal administration. Contrary to the wild-type forms, attenuated viruses have the capacity to replicate well at temperatures around 25 °C rather than at 37 °C, deterring their replication in the lower airway, including lung tissue, and the subsequent occurrence of influenza-like disease [ 80]. The most important feature of LAIVs is that they elicit a minor infection at the site of challenge and present a high degree of antigen exposure [ 81]. Ideally, LAIVs have been constructed to possess a limited replication capacity to avoid undesirable inflammatory response while delivering a sufficiently high dose of antigens at the site of administration [ 82].
